body.p: The number of people in a car that crosses a certain bridge is represented by the random variable X, which has a mean value μX = 2.7, and a variance σ2X = 1.2. The toll on the bridge is $3.00 per car plus $0.50 per person in the car.

What is the mean of the total amount of money that is collected from a car that crosses the bridge? Report your answer to two decimal places. Do NOT include a dollar sign ($) when reporting your answer.

What is the variance of the total amount of money that is collected from a car that crosses the bridge? Report your answer to two decimal places. Do NOT include a dollar sign ($) when reporting your answer.

response.feedback: Correct. Let T be the total amount of money that is collected from a car that crosses the bridge. multiple_choice.body: Suppose Blue Cab Company charges $2.85 a ride up to 0.1 miles and $0.30 for each additional tenth of a mile. If the mean distance a passenger wants to go is 5.3 miles with a standard deviation of 1.4 miles, what is the mean of the fare passengers pay?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Let T be the total amount of the cab fare. It looks as though you used the equation μ(a+bX) = a + b μX but you used b = $0.30 which is the price per 1/10 of a mile not the price per mile. The pricing is given in miles, not 1/10 of miles so we need to set b = $3.00. It is also important to note that μX = 5.3 − 0.1 = 5.2 because the $2.85 includes the first 0.1 miles of the trip.

Correct. The key was to convert the rate to dollars per mile from dollars per tenth of a mile so b = 3 and to set μX = 5.3 − 0.1 = 5.2 since the first 10th of a mile was included in the fixed fee. Therefore, the mean is $2.85 + $3.00(5.2) = 2.85 + 15.60 = $18.45.
Incorrect. It looks at though you set b = $3.00 but you forgot to compensate for the fact that the first 1/10 mile was included in the $2.85 fixed fee, so μX = 5.3 − 0.1 = 5.2.
